note.p: William B. Anderson's letter dated July 1, 1863 from Cincinnati and addressed to his wife Louisa is written in ink on one side of a loose sheet of paper measuring approximately 7.5 inches wide by 9.0 inches tall (19 x 23 cm) and ruled with horizontal blue lines spaced .33 inches (0.8 cm) apart, except for a 1.5-inch (3.8 cm) unruled top margin. The left edge of the sheet is slightly ragged, while the other three edges are clean, suggesting that the sheet was torn from a notepad or bound notebook. It appears originally to have been folded once crosswise and twice lengthwise. At this writing, the ink appears brown and the paper off-white (cream). A .5-inch by .5-inch (1.3 x 1.3 cm) embossed printer's mark appears in the upper lefthand corner of the sheet, 0.5 inches (1.3 cm) from the top edge and .25 inches (0.6 cm) from the left edge. It reads "MT HOLLY PAPER CO" (see illustration).

projectDesc.p: This particular letter from William B. Anderson to his wife, Mary Louisa, was written in Cincinnati in the summer (July 1) of 1863. It deals with the typical issues that are included in many of the Anderson letters from the summer (1862-64). Issues of maintaining the family, business, and financial prosperity are dealt with in this particular letter to Mary Louisa. The issue of managing these affairs from a long distance is one which is important when trying to understand the Anderson Letters, as it pertains to the life of a riverboat captain and his family. William Anderson had to attend to his family affairs through letters that were often written under rushed, shaky circumstances.

This letter from July 1, 1863 is a very good indication of the commitment William Anderson had to his wife Louisa and their family. While knee deep in the busy lifestyle of a riverboat captain on the Ohio River – which was thriving with commerce and was a critical waterway during this time period of the Civil War – William Anderson underwent the hardships one would experience in such circumstances.

We see that William Anderson was shipping Government freight at this time, which includes potatoes, horse wagons, ambulances, and horses. The fact that Anderson was shipping ambulances and horses and horse wagons implicates the importance of the cargo that he is shipping, thus implicating the importance of his job as the riverboat captain. Anderson writes about the hard work which is made harder in the summer heat. His hard work and the implications of that work points to the magnanimous importance of riverboats, and most relevant in the case of the Anderson Letters, it points the importance of the Ohio River as a critical waterway for commerce and for shipping cargo that was relevant in terms of the Civil War.

William Anderson’s emphasis on financial issues and family issues are dominant in this letter, from July 1, 1863. The duality of lifestyles as a family man and a riverboat captain indicate William Anderson’s commitment to his tasks in life. At the same token, we can see the importance of Anderson’s wife, Mary Louisa, upholding the family back in Pittsburgh by taking care of the children and some of the financial affairs. Specifically, William Anderson tells Mary Louisa she can get sugar from places in either Pittsburgh or Allegheny, and that he will send her money or she can get some from John Russell.

Anderson exclaims his pleasure in hearing from his wife. He tells her to kiss the little ones for him, which is a statement that is seen in multiple letters from William Anderson to Mary Louisa. He also states that he is busy all the time or he would write more. This letter indicates that the summer time is very busy for riverboats. Again, the importance of the riverboats, and the Ohio River, are seen in this letter, but at the same time the importance of family for William Anderson shows up throughout this particular letter and the collection of Anderson Letters as a whole.

It is important that through editing these editions of of the Anderson letters we maintain a user friendly base for our electronic editions. Kevin Kiernan states in an article titled, "Electronic Textual Editing: Digital Facsimiles in Editing", that "The apparatus, a Help function always a click away, should be comprehensive, incorporating such concepts as contents, preface, acknowledgments, introduction, footnotes, and endnotes (whether explanatory or textual), glossary, appendices, index, and bibliography." The concept of creating an informative, user friendly edition of the Anderson letters, while maintaining the integrity of the letters, is an important aspect which we (as a class) have tried to incorporate into these letters.

editorialDecl.p: Encoding of the Anderson letters emphasizes diplomatic transcription, with supplemental information allowing for semi-modernized, corrected, regularized, or expanded views included as the values of attributes associated with various elements. Accordingly, abbreviations, recoverable cancelations, punctuation, spelling, underscoring, capitalization, line breaks, and page breaks have all been transcribed or tagged as they appear in the original manuscripts. Regularized versions of all names and referring strings have been encoded as the values of "reg" attributes. Standard format values for all dates have been encoded in "value" attributes.

Corrections and emendations in Anderson's hand have been encoded as cancelations and interlinear or marginal additions. In a few cases, omitted text has been supplied by the editors for the sake of clarity and encoded with the TEI <supplied> element.

The following structural elements of the letters are also encoded: opener (including salutation and dateline), body, lines, paragraphs, pages, and closers (including salutation and signature). Notes and postscripts are identified as such.
The critical apparatus used in particular views of the letters is explained at the bottom of each view.

refsDecl.p: The XML files that constitute this edition of the William B. Anderson letters are named according the letters' dates of composition, using the following naming convention: WBA_YYYYMMDD.xml. Dates of composition were determined from various sources of evidence: the datelines inscribed in the letters, internal evidence in the body of the letters, and perpetual calendars. If the year, month, or date on which a letter was written could not be determined, the appropriate part of the filename is rendered with 0s. XSL style sheet documents are named with the prefix "WBA" followed by an underscore and a descriptive phrase (e.g., "WBA_diplomatic.xsl).

In general, this edition follows the Text Encoding Initiative's Guidelines for Electronic Text Encoding and Interchange, XML-compatible edition P4. For more information about TEI P4, see http://www.tei-c.org/P4X/. To facilitate embedding or linking to image, audio, and video files, this edition supplements the Text Encoding Initiative's DTD by adding a URL attribute to the <xref> element and an MMID (i.e., Media Manager ID) attribute to the <pb> element. The values of the MMID attribute in <pb> elements and the file IDs in the URL attribute of <xref> elements that link to, or embed, image, audio, and video files contained in the Media Manager are generated by the Media Manager application.

bibl.title: A letter from William B. Anderson to his wife, Mary Louisa, from July 1, 1863 written in Cincinnati

div1.p: In this letter, from July 1, 1863, William B. Anderson writes to his wife, Mary Louisa, from Cincinnati. Anderson tells his wife about the Government cargo he is shipping, and the hard work that goes along with handling the cargo in the summer heat. Anderson also gives Mary Louisa advice pertaining to family and financial affairs back home in Pittsburgh. He ends the letter as he does most, with affection for his wife and telling her to kiss "the little ones" for him.
Previous letter 19 June 1863 Next letter 5 July 1863

As I have an opportunity of sending
you a letter by Mr Wm Russell I thought I
would embrace the opportunity. I am well and hope
you are also. we start this evening for Nashville2
Our cargo is principally Gov. Frt we have for
one item 1000 Barrels Potatoes there is lots of frt
to Go to Nashville I had the offer of 280
six Horses Waggons 150 ambulances and Horses for
June and 450 tons clothing. I take 100 tons or
one thousand Barrels Potatoes and as many
boxes of Clothing As I can carry on the water
which will amt to in all about 1500$ Dolls
for Potatoes and about 12 to 1500$ for the Bal
which is in all about a three thousand Dlr Trip
& if we get safe there & back we will make
a good trip it is excessively Hot today I can
scarcely stand it but I hope we will have it
Cooler when we get underway. I have been very
buissily engaged all day have had a good ell
of work to do to get our trip secured there is a
good many way of dodging. I can not tell
you when I will be home I had some hope of
selling but now all chances have escaped
I will make this trip and I cannot tell you
what I will do next If I cannot make it pay
& I don’t sell I will lay up till Cool weather
it is murdering ones self by degrees to Boat
such times as those. I suppose you have best
get a Barrell of N.O. Sugar at Pitt either
from Holmes & Co Market St3 or from Mirer and
Robinson Allegheny 4 I would send you the
Money but I suppose you can get it from
Russell 5 it will cost about 35 or 40 Dolls
you can get Russell to get it for you and
let him charge it. I will send him a
note by Bill and he can get it and have it
sent to his store have him get it over
the River & all.

I have no news to write about but to
say your letter the first one came yesterday
and I was pleased to hear from you
give my love to all the little ones
and Kiss them for me
div1.closer:
Ever your affectionate Husband
WB Anderson
P.S.
I am interupted all the time or
I would write more
good bye for a while
WBA

div1.note: 1. Mary Louisa Fischgens (1837-1911) was the wife of William B. Anderson, and mother of their five children."History of Allegheny County"
2. Nashville, Tennessee could be reached from the Ohio River via the Cumberland River, which meets the Ohio at mile 933.
